summary: Starwood's Barry Sternlicht said the stock market would suffer from a Democratic sweep.
headline: Barry Sternlicht sees a 'significant correction in high flying stocks' with a Democratic Sweep
NFL postpones Titans-Steelers Week 4 game after positive Covid-19 tests
summary: The NFL said the Tennessee Titans-Pittsburgh Steelers game would is postponed after eight new Covid-19 cases.

headline: Vista's Robert Smith says there are more opportunities in private markets than public right now
summary: "There's actually a large number of software companies that are actually getting to a state of maturity," Smith said.

headline: Nets owner Joseph Tsai sees next season as 'tricky' but expects a 'very nice rebound'
summary: Brooklyn Nets owner Joseph Tsai envisions arenas still without a lot of fans next season though he expects that to turn around in the ensuing years.

headline: Shepard Smith on his success: ‘I never said no. Not to one assignment’
summary: Shepard Smith says he worked nights and weekends for decades, often forgetting about his personal life, to succeed as a journalist. Now, with "The News with Shepard Smith" on CNBC, Smith hopes the show will be "a full-plate newscast" that offers the news of the day and some perspective, that points out the heroes amid the chaos, and tells some good news, too.
The COVID-19 pandemic seems to have changed everything, but when it comes to emerging markets, the things that matter the most for investors have remained consistent.

headline: Disney leads companies announcing layoffs; big airline job cuts loom
summary: Companies are cutting jobs as the coronavirus pandemic stretches on.

headline: Airlines are hours away from cutting more than 30,000 jobs without billions more in federal aid
summary: Airline executives at American, United, Southwest and JetBlue have been making last-ditch attempts to persuade lawmakers to provide additional aid as the job cuts loom.
The change means that Facebook users can now message Instagram users without needing to download a new app, and vice versa.
headline: Facebook integrates Messenger with Instagram in first move toward unified chat apps
Can New York reopen indoor dining safely? Here is what coronavirus, dining experts say
summary: As New York City restaurants reopen indoor dining at 25% capacity, Union Square Hospitality Group founder and CEO Danny Meyer has partnered with biometric screening company CLEAR to monitor employee health during coronavirus.
"Where I come out as a businessman, I will take the devil I know over the devil I don't know anytime of the week," BET founder Robert Johnson told CNBC.
headline: BET founder Robert Johnson says 'I will take the devil I know,' adding he doesn't know what Biden will do
Amazon vs. Target: Traders weigh in on the stocks ahead of competing sales events
summary: Amazon and Target are going head to head with their sales events mid-October, and trader Boris Schlossberg said "I think both companies can succeed."

headline: Bloomberg Westminster: Backing Boris on Covid Curbs

summary: Palantir and Asana were co-founded and financed by billionaires who made fortunes from their early involvement in Facebook.
headline: Facebook's billions are backing two tech direct listings on Wednesday: Palantir and Asana
Treasury Department could upsize airline loans as Delta, Southwest opt out, freeing up funds
summary: The Treasury Department says it plans to upsize loans to airlines under a $25 billion federal program after major carriers Delta and Southwest decided to stick with the private market.

headline: China says manufacturing activity expanded in September
summary: China's official manufacturing Purchasing Manager's Index (PMI) for the month of September came in at 51.5 as compared to 51.0 in August, according to the country's National Bureau of Statistics.
With more Americans spending time in the great outdoors amid the coronavirus pandemic, the trend has lead to a glut in inventory at recreational vehicle dealerships.
headline: Polaris, Thor Industries boost RV production as 'unprecedented demand' weighs on inventories
Apple CEO Tim Cook receives first major stock grant since 2011, could earn more than 1 million shares by 2025
summary: The stock grant suggests that Cook's performance over the past decade is viewed highly by Apple's board, which wants to make sure that he will be paid competitively through 2025 if he continues to be the CEO of Apple.

headline: The home cooking trend is 'becoming a habit,' says CEO of spice maker McCormick
Stocks will return to record highs regardless of election outcome, $300M money manager predicts
summary: WealthWise Financial CEO Loreen Gilbert is building her bull case on the economic recovery.
